sections.title: Landlord Entry Requirements
sections.text: In Texas, landlords must provide reasonable notice before entering a rental unit, typically 24 hours. Entry must be for a legitimate purpose (repairs, inspections, showings). Entry without notice or at unreasonable times may violate tenant privacy rights under Texas Property Code.

sections.title: Security Deposit Requirements
sections.text: In Texas, security deposits must be refundable and returned within 30 days of lease termination. Landlords must provide itemized deductions and cannot make deposits 'non-refundable' or exercise unilateral discretion over returns. There are no statutory limits on deposit amounts, but refundability is required.

sections.title: Warranty of Habitability
sections.text: Landlords must maintain rental units in habitable condition with working heat, air conditioning (in some areas), plumbing, and compliance with housing codes. Tenants may exercise 'repair and deduct' remedies if landlords fail to make necessary repairs. Essential repairs cannot be shifted to tenants.

sections.title: Protection Against Retaliatory Eviction
sections.text: Landlords cannot evict tenants in retaliation for exercising their rights, such as filing complaints about housing code violations, requesting repairs, or organizing with other tenants. Retaliatory evictions are illegal under Texas Property Code.
